content.description: Sit start with a left hand on a sloping jug, and a right hand on a sloping crimp.  From there, crank a right heel to reach the sloping shelf above.  Then traverse left, around the bulge on the slopers until the shelf feature ends, and top it out.
content.protection: Pad or two and a spot.
content.location: On the North-face of the Rubber Rock, the problem starts about 4 feet from the water's edge on the northwest corner.

content.description: Start at a good jug and follow more good holds to the top.

Start at some good jug holds. From there, you'll you need to get into position to get a hold of the overhanging ledge.  Then move right a little to a good top out hold. There are lots of good feet to help on the way up.
content.protection: Pad & spotter. You might want to do some cleaning as some holds do accumulate some sand and leaves.

content.description:
Depending on the time of year you go, this is a "deep" water bouldering spot in the desert.

Start either matched on an obvious rail system or with a left hand on the side pull and right hand on the rail. Move to the right on slopers and crimps. When you traverse around the bend, start to move upward.

The crux is right in the middle over 5 feet of water (at least when we went in the spring).
content.protection: No pads, just bathing suits. There are no rocks under the water, just mud.
content.location: It is on the back side (southwest) side of Rubber Rock. There's a downclimb using a large pile of wood on the back side.
